comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/] Many Thanks for uploading this!
There appears to be no 'hand' logo on the chainwheel of the Rudge-Whitworth
bicycle on the left, but it appears on the pair of small trophies!
Definitely something funny about their faces, the eyes especially!?
There was a Rudge-Whitworth dealership at 1, Stephen's Green North, in Dublin.

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: Actually, the Rudge-Whitworth dealership in Waterford was in Henrietta Street!!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abaraphobia] And here is that very dealership, by appointment to HRH The Prince of Wales...

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] There was a motorcyle/bicycle dealer called W.F.Peare in Henrietta Street, who appeared to occupy this premises- www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/5735786427/ , as shown in your photostream, shortly after your bicycle photos were taken! They sold other makes of bicycles than Rudge-Whitworth, though! Could it be possible that Mr. Keane is in fact Mr. Peare!?

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: The trouble with studio photographs was you either went for natural daylight or a tray of flash powder. I would say this is naturally lighted meaning that the subject(s) must not blink for quite a long time due to the extremely slow shutter speed. This makes them look as if they are staring at something. The speed of a glass negative may be around 16ASA in those days.

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: The motorcycle dealer on Henrietta Street, Waterford was William Cordner. WF Peare built Ireland's first purpose-built motor garage on Catherine Street in 1900 - a premises still in use as a motor garage today. The men holding the bicycles in the earlier photograph are adopting the position they would use when starting a bicycle and rider off at the start of a race. I don't think it is the case but the head of the man second from left and the man sitting on the floor on the right almost have the appearance of being from different photographs and re-touched in. The lighting is much better in the first photograph.

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: There's an ad for Peare's Cycle Depot on Henrietta Street here- www.askaboutireland.ie/reading-room/environment-geography... Here's Cordner's, on this page- www.boards.ie/vbulletin/showthread.php?p=75032369 I suppose Rudge-Whitworth must have had a different premises to either of those?

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: looks like a bad Photoshop job, if such a thing existed 100 yrs ago...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
As both of our South Eastern Wheelers photos were taken on Sunday, 4 July 1909, I had a bit of a rummage through our run of The Irish Cyclist. We have this fantastic publication right from Vol. I, no. 1, May 1885 and I have to say that if you're interested in Irish cycling (and then motorcycling) it is a quite amazing resource... Plug for NLI material done with, I found this - Munster Notes in The Irish Cyclist, 23 June 1909:
Challenge Cup Presented. The Rudge-Whitworth Cycle Co. have presented to the South-Eastern Wheelers, Waterford, a valuable silver cup to be put up as a challenge cup for a road race of 25 miles, confined to cyclists in the South-Eastern jurisdiction of the I.C.A. The date of the contest has not yet been definitely fixed, but I understand it is intended to hold the race at the end of July. There should be very keen competition for this valuable trophy, which is now being exhibited in the windows of Mr. R. Whelan, Jeweller, Barronstrand Street.
I followed the trail right through July and August to see if I could find more on the silverware and the race involved, but the trail grew cold. However, again from Munster Notes in The Irish Cyclist, 4 August 1909:
Waterford Wheelers. That live Waterford Club, the South-Eastern Wheelers, have been holding some road events lately ... second berth being occupied by A. Keane, another Waterford man...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: Very interesting to learn that Peare's had a "Cycle Depot" on Henrietta Street in addition to the motor garage on Catherine Street. I've lately been in touch with some of 'Bill' Peare's descendants in Ireland, Chicago and Britain and I'm not sure that any of them were aware of it either! All goes to show the great value of this site.

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: I came across this actual photograph which appears in The Irish Cyclist issue of September 1st 1909 captioned 'The South-Eastern Wheelers Racing Team'. In the RIAC Archive we have an incomplete run of The Irish Cyclist'. I'm currently looking for the 1913 volumes and Jan-June 1912. Do you have these volumes in your collection?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] I think so, Bob, we have a pretty complete run. I'm working in the stacks tomorrow morning so I'll check for you then...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
